24.text: First in the spotlight tonight is the Blue Peter presenter Radzi.

28.text: He's answering questions on that great sitcom The Office.

32.text: Next, the singer and songwriter Damon Gough,

35.text: otherwise known as Badly Drawn Boy.

41.text: The actress Rebecca Root answering questions on the novels of Graham Greene.

46.text: And the Olympic athlete Kriss Akabusi on West Ham United.

60.text: Hello and welcome to Celebrity Mastermind,

64.text: with me, John Humphrys, and four celebrities who think

67.text: they know everything they need to know about their specialist subjects,

71.text: but what they don't know is what affect the black chair will have on them

75.text: when they finally get to sit in it.

77.text: Their fees go to charity, but the prize for one of them

80.text: is the trophy, and the honour of becoming a Mastermind.

84.text: The rules are the same, though.

86.text: 90 seconds of questions on their specialist subject, and then two minutes on general knowledge.

90.text: So, let us get on with it, and ask our first contender to join us, please.

107.text: The Office. Here we go. 90 seconds.

110.text: The mockumentary sitcom The Office was written and directed

113.text: by Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant,

114.text: and depicts the day-to-day lives of employees

116.text: at the paper merchants Wernham Hogg.

118.text: What is the title of the show's theme song?

124.text: At the start of the second series, the Slough branch of Wernham Hogg

126.text: incorporates the staff of another branch in which town?

129.text:
- Swindon. 
- Yep. After the office quiz,

131.text: Finchy forces David Brent to admit that instead of Fidel Castro,

134.text: he gave a ridiculous answer to the question, "Name the Cuban leader

137.text: "who's been in power since the Revolution of 1959."

142.text: When Brent is made redundant and sues Wernham Hogg,

144.text: the UK manager, Neil Godwin makes it clear that Brent's social calls

148.text: are no longer welcome. What is the name of Brent's dog,

150.text: who's also barred from the office?

153.text: To raise money for Comic Relief, Brent gives an impromptu demonstration

156.text: of his dance moves, which he describes as a fusion of MC Hammer with which film?

162.text: who interviews Brent for the trade magazine Inside Paper?

168.text: When Brent sees that Gareth is wearing a holster to

170.text: hold his mobile phone, he does an impression of which film actor?

173.text:
- Clint Eastwood. 
- Yes, playing Dirty Harry.

176.text: When Brent is preparing for his motivational talks,

178.text: he asks Gareth to throw insults at him,

180.text: and he discovers that because of his appearance, his nicknames around the office

184.text: are Mr Toad and also which cartoon character?

187.text: On Keith from accounts' appraisal form,

189.text: he lists accounts as his only strength.

191.text: What does he put under weaknesses?

194.text: What Secret Santa gift does Dawn get from Tim

197.text: at the Christmas party, together with a note saying, "Never give up."

222.text:
- And your name is... 
- Damon Gough.

224.text:
- Your chosen charity. 
- The WESC Foundation.

227.text:
- And your specialist subject. 
- The career and life of Bruce Springsteen.

231.text: Bruce Springsteen, in 90 seconds, here we go.

234.text: Which music critic, who later became Springsteen's manager and producer,

239.text: and wrote "I saw rock and roll future and its name is Bruce Springsteen?"

244.text: At which London venue did Springsteen make his UK debut in November 1975?

251.text: Springsteen was reputedly inspired to become a musician

253.text: after watching a performance by Presley,

255.text: on which Sunday night television variety show?

259.text: Who replaced Ernest Boom Carter as the drummer in Springsteen's backing group,

263.text: The E Street Band, in the summer of 1974?

266.text: Which track on Springsteen's 1975 album Born To Run was originally called The Heist

271.text: and depicts two small-time criminals preparing for a robbery?

275.text: Who was Springsteen's manager with whom he had a long legal dispute

278.text: which seriously limited his recording output in 1976 and '77?

284.text: What is the title of Springsteen's 1998 four-CD box set of rare outtakes

288.text: and other previously unreleased material from recording sessions?

292.text: Who does Springsteen pull up on stage and dance with

295.text: in Brian De Palma's video for Dancing In The Dark?

297.text: She went on to star in Friends.

299.text: Which song on Springsteen's debut album, Greetings From Asbury Park, NJ,

303.text: "I was the king of the alley, mama, I could talk some trash.

306.text: "I was the prince of the paupers, crowned downtown at the beggar's bash."

309.text:
- It's Hard To Be A Saint In The City. 
- Yes.

311.text: The title song of which '95 album was inspired by, and makes references to,

315.text: John Steinbeck's novel The Grapes of Wrath?

318.text:
- The Ghost of Tom Joad. 
- Yeah.

319.text: What is the title of Springsteen's album, released in January 2014,

322.text: which contains outtakes, covers and reworkings... BEEP ..of his own songs?

328.text:
- A Promise. 
- Oh, what a shame, no. High Hopes.

331.text:
- But, nonetheless, you've got, Damon, 10 points. 
- Thank you.

352.text:
- And your name is... 
- Rebecca Root.

361.text: Graham Greene's novels, in 90 seconds. Here we go.

364.text: In Our Man In Havana, the everyday occupation of James Wormold who was offered work with

367.text: the British Secret Services selling what household item?

371.text: In Brighton Rock, what's the name of the older gang member who was uncomfortable with

375.text: the growing violence of the mob?

376.text: Pinkie kills him so the murder of Charles Hale can't be reported.

380.text: In the Heart of the Matter, Edward Wilson and his housemate Harris

383.text: quarrel about the rules of engagement for hunting what insects?

387.text: What's the profession of Mr Tench, who befriends a nameless priest

390.text: after meeting him at the quayside in The Power and the Glory?

392.text:
- He's a dentist. 
- He is. In The End of the Affair, after Sarah Myles dies from a fever,

396.text: her husband, Henry, invites Sarah's lover Morris to take any memento from her desk.

402.text: In The Heart of the Matter, Major Scobie tries to arrange for his wife

404.text: to travel for another country where she thinks she'll be happier.

407.text: What country does she want to go to?

409.text:
- South Africa. 
- Yep. In Travels With My Aunt, what flower does Henry Pulling

412.text: tell his Aunt Augusta he spends his time cultivating when he meets her

415.text: at his mother's funeral after many years separation?

417.text:
- Dahlias. 
- Yeah. In Dr Fisher of Geneva, at the first party that Alfred Jones attends,

421.text: he's told the guests who obey instructions received expensive gifts

424.text: at the end of the meal. What must they eat to get their prize?

428.text: What does Pinkie Brown tell Rose was splashed in the eyes and face

431.text: of Peggy Barton to spoil her looks?

434.text: In The Human Factory, Davis's secretary appears upset at her boss's funeral,

439.text: causing Dr Percival to explain to Morris that Davis was in love with her.

445.text: Detective Sgt Sparrow confiscates Henry Pulling's mother's ashes

448.text: and has them tested, revealing that something has been mixed in

451.text: with them in the urn. What?

454.text: Alfred Jones attends... BEEP ..Dr Fisher's last party where guests must

458.text: pick a cracker. One has a bomb in it.

460.text: The others each contain a cheque for how many francs?

462.text:
- Two million Swiss francs. 
- Yeah. Absolutely.

465.text: You got them all right. 12 points.

488.text:
- And your chosen subject. 
- The mighty West Ham!

584.text: by the club's... BEEP ..new owners David Sullivan and David Gold,

592.text: You had a few passes, Kriss.

594.text: It was the Emirates Stadium where they became the first away team to win a competitive game.

599.text: The rather naughty defender who got all those red cards was Tomas Repka,

604.text: and Matthew Upson wore the number 6 and then the number 15 shirt.

609.text:
- You've scored, Kriss, 7 points. 
- Thank you very much.

621.text: Well, some very good scoring there.

623.text: Let's have a look at all the scores.

624.text: In fourth place, 7 points, Kriss Akabusi.

643.text: and if there is a tie at the end of it,

645.text: then the number of passes is taken into account,

647.text: and the person with the fewer passes is the winner,

656.text: you were the third-best sprinter in the world.

659.text: Not in Britain, in the world. And you seemed to be disappointed with that?

664.text: I mean, certainly when you start off in your career, you know,

667.text: you want to be the best in your country,

669.text: then you become the best in Europe, and it's great,

671.text: and then you try to be the best in the world.

673.text: Every now and again, you look up, no-one's there, everyone's down there.

676.text: For me, I got to third, looked up, there's two people, I said,

680.text: Just a quick word about athletics.

682.text: Very, very different world today to what the amateur world was.

688.text: Better for the sport, I mean.

691.text: Well, I mean, obviously, there's been a lot of scandal this year. Um...

696.text: You know, you want to be pure, but you also... I think...

699.text: It is a good idea that someone who dedicates 15 years of life to

702.text: something, that they actually can make a living out of it too,

705.text: so I don't begrudge the people who are making good money today.

708.text: If you're someone like Usain Bolt for example,

710.text: and you bring so much joy and you do such phenomenal stuff,

713.text: you shouldn't have to work again when you finish your sport.

717.text: Right, well, now, you already have 7 points, and you now have

895.text: And you start out with 9 points, Radzi.

901.text: Um... Some things have changed, but most things haven't.

904.text: I mean, you still make things and you still do challenges.

909.text: and it's kind of the stalwart of Children's BBC, I guess,

912.text: and it's a privilege to be on it,

913.text: but it's still fundamentally the same, we hope to inspire kids and...

919.text: though, do you? Or do you?

920.text: Loo rolls, we do, sticky back plastic, we sometimes do!

923.text: But, yeah, the makes really vary -

926.text: we make things similar to that and try and keep it a legendary show.

929.text: And the challenges, are they more daring than they were?

932.text: Although they were pretty daring in the old days!

935.text: Yeah, I think we have been daring throughout.

937.text: For me personally, I have got to swim Lake Windermere,

939.text: I have climbed the tallest man-made climbing wall in the world,

945.text:
- Crumbs! How high is that? 
- 165 metres.

949.text: So, yeah, there was little old me, ten training sessions,

952.text: off I go to Switzerland and hopefully scale this big wall.

956.text: And is there one challenge you think, they are going to ring me

959.text: one day and say, "We want you to..."

961.text: and you're going to say, "Uh-uh, no, couldn't do that"?

963.text:
- I've got a thing about sharks. 
- Ah!

967.text: I don't really want to get in any water with any sharks.

969.text: I really like the land, I like how gravity works on my body,

972.text: I will leave sharks to what they do, so, I don't want that call,

975.text:
- but anything else, I'm game for. 
- Well, long may it last.

1156.text: I don't know whether to call you Badly Drawn Boy or what!

1161.text: I mean, why Badly Drawn Boy? I'm sure everyone has asked you that.

1164.text:
- Call me what you like, John. 
- Yeah? 
- You are the presenter of Mastermind!

1167.text: I know, but I still don't know why you're called Badly Drawn Boy.

1170.text: It was just a name that I made up, um,

1173.text: over a bottle of wine one night...

1175.text: I think it had gone off, the bottle of wine, this name just came

1191.text:
- You won it for The Hour of Bewilderbeest.

1196.text: as it were, and you win THE prize, the big prize?

1199.text: It just makes you really big headed and unbearable to be around!

1204.text: It was like, you couldn't really plan for something like that

1207.text: to happen. I was dead proud of it.

1209.text: In fact, you are now touring again, aren't you, with Bewilderbeest?

1212.text: Yeah, this year was the 15th anniversary of the first album,

1216.text: that won the Mercury Prize, so I wanted to sort of pay

1220.text: reverence to it, because I think at the time I was just...

1222.text: I was bowled over by it all,

1224.text: so it's been a really nice year in terms of playing that record again

1228.text: at some gigs and say thanks to people for keeping

1231.text:
- it in their lives.
